text: Cross-linking of <extra_id_0> CD30 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induces HIV expression in chronically infected T cells .

<extra_id_0> CD30 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , a member of the tumor necrosis factor ( TNF ) receptor family , is expressed constitutively on the surface of the human T cell line ACH-2 , which is chronically infected with human immunodeficiency virus type-1 ( HIV ) -1 .

We demonstrate that cross-linking <extra_id_0> CD30 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> with an anti - <extra_id_0> CD30 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - specific monoclonal antibody , which mimics the described biological activities of the <extra_id_0> CD30 ligand <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> CD30L <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , results in HIV expression .

text: <extra_id_0> CD30 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> cross-linking does not alter proliferation of ACH-2 cells and the induction of HIV expression is not mediated by endogenous <extra_id_0> TNF alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
Furthermore , cross-linking of <extra_id_0> CD30 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> leads to NF-kappa B activation and enhanced HIV transcription .

Thus , <extra_id_0> CD30 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - <extra_id_0> CD30L <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> interactions mediate the induction of HIV expression by a kappa B - dependent pathway that is independent of TNF .
event: <extra_id_0> <extra_id_0> Binding interactions <extra_id_0> Theme CD30 <extra_id_1> <extra_id_0> Theme CD30L <extra_id_1> <extra_id_1> <extra_id_1>

text: This mechanism may be important in the activation of HIV expression from latently infected <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells , especially in lymphoid organs where cell to cell contact is conducive to receptor - ligand interactions .
